Artistic & participatory research methods  I joined The University of Manchester in a research position in 2013, when I was awarded a PhD studentship.  In September 2018 I  was awarded a 3 year Early Career Research Fellowship by the Leverhulme Trust. I am currently conducting a 3 year international comparative research project funded by the Trust - Redefining Education for an Urban Social Solidarity Economy: Becoming Relational. The project Redefining Education for an Urban Social Solidarity Economy: Becoming Relational considers how more relational approaches to policy, governance, curriculum & pedagogy impact on relationships, not only between institutions & their stakeholders but can positively impact more widely on democracy & social justice in urban places.  The research explores how urban policymakers & academics are conceptualising and/or operationalising the links between a social solidarity urban economy & the development of education policy/ governance/curriculum or pedagogy.  I compare the views of professionals with the lived experiences of children, young people and their communities. Using visual & artistic methods & participatory mapping techniques, children and young people create participant artefacts that foreground their opinions, feelings & experiences.  The approach is an attempt to better understand the lived realities of children and young people‚Äôs urban education experiences and the extent to which they feel that there has been an attempt to make their city/urban neighbourhood more inclusive and equitable through its education polices and practices.
